questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents with sudden, severe visual loss following a recent road traffic accident involving chest trauma. Fundus examination reveals multiple white retinal patches near the optic disc, cotton wool spots, and minimal intraretinal hemorrhage. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Description

Etiology

Trauma (head, chest), fractures, systemic diseases like SLE, pancreatitis, pre-eclampsia.

Fundoscopy features
  • Purtscher Flecken: White patches near the optic disc and fovea due to arteriolar occlusion.
  • Cotton Wool Spots: Infarcts in the nerve fiber layer, typically restricted to the posterior pole.
  • Retinal Hemorrhages: Small, low-to-moderate hemorrhages.

Diagnostic Criteria

Requires 3 out of 5:

  • Purtscher flecken
  • Hemorrhages
  • Cotton wool spots
  • Plausible cause
  • Investigation compatible with the diagnosis

Ocular investigations
  • Fundus Fluorescein Angiography (FFA): Reveals macular ischemia, capillary nonperfusion, and optic nerve head leakage.
  • Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT): Demonstrates retinal thickening, subretinal fluid, and photoreceptor loss in later stages.
  • OCT Angiography: Can show retinal capillary ischemia.

Management

Supportive care, steroids, anti-VEGF for macular edema.

questions.text: A 30-week premature infant weighing 1.4 kg is diagnosed with stage 3 retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) in zone II without plus disease. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Zone I

Bounded by a circle, the radius of which is twice the distance between the center of the optic disc and center of the macula.

Zone II

Extends from the edge of the zone 1 peripherally to a point tangential to the nasal ora serrata.

Zone III

Consists of residual temporal crescent of retina anterior to zone II.

Type I

Type II

High-Risk Prethreshold Disease, requiring laser photocoagulation.

  • Zone I: Plus disease, any stage.
  • Zone I: Non-plus disease, stage 3.
  • Zone II: Plus disease, stages 2 and 3. (Option A)

Low-Risk Prethreshold Disease, requiring weekly follow-up.

  • Zone I: Non-plus disease, stages 1 and 2.
  • Zone II: Non-plus disease, stage 3. (Option C)

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden, painless vision loss in his right eye. On examination, the right eye shows a pale retina with a cherry-red spot at the macula. The patient has a history of hypertension and smoking. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment to improve retinal blood flow and potentially restore vision?

options.label: C
options.text: Ocular massage and anterior chamber paracentesis

questions.correct_answer: C. Ocular massage and anterior chamber paracentesis
questions.explanation:
Treatment Goals

Restore Blood Flow

Dislodge or break down the blockage in the central retinal artery as quickly as possible.

Minimize Retinal Damage

Limit the duration of ischemia to reduce permanent damage to retinal tissue.

Address Underlying Conditions

Identify and manage underlying conditions like atherosclerosis, hypertension, and cardiac diseases.

Treatment Options

Ocular Massage (within 24 hrs)

Apply pressure to the globe to dislodge the embolus; performed using a three-mirror contact lens.

Anterior Chamber Paracentesis

Withdraw aqueous humor to decrease intraocular pressure, potentially dislodging the embolus.

Medications to Lower IOP

  

Topical Apraclonidine & Timolol

Reduce aqueous humor production to lower IOP

Intravenous Acetazolamide (Option C)

Provides sustained IOP reduction

Vasodilators

  

Sublingual Isosorbide Dinitrate (Option D)

Dilates blood vessels to improve blood flow past the blockage

Carbon Dioxide Inhalation

  

"Rebreathing" into a Paper Bag

Increases carbon dioxide levels to induce vasodilation

Carbogen Breathing

Controlled inhalation of high oxygen (95%) and carbon dioxide (5%) mixtures to induce vasodilation and slow down ischemia.

Hyperosmotic agents

Mannitol or glycerol (Option A&B)

Rapid IOP-lowering effect and raised intravascular volume

Transluminal Nd:YAG laser embolysis/embolectomy

For BRAO and CRAO where an occluding embolus is visible; Good final visual results achieved

Thrombolysis

  

Local Intra-arterial or Intravenous

Directly dissolve clots with thrombolytic agents; efficacy in CRAO is inconclusive.

Local Intraocular Thrombolysis

Use of rtPA for thrombolysis; large trials show no significant benefit

Systemic Management

  

Urgent Referral

Immediate evaluation by a stroke specialist due to high stroke risk.

Management of Risk Factors

Smoking Cessation

Reduce overall vascular risk.

Cardiac Arrhythmia Management

Refer to a physician for conditions like atrial fibrillation.

Antiplatelet Therapy

To reduce further blood clot formation, unless contraindicated.

Oral Anticoagulation

Warfarin or other anticoagulants for conditions like atrial fibrillation

Carotid Endarterectomy

Considered for significant carotid artery stenosis.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with a 20-year history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes and an HbA1c of 10.5% came for an ophthalmic examination. Fundoscopy reveals microaneurysms, hard exudates, and retinal thickening. Which of the following is the most likely cause of future vision loss in this patient?

A 64-year-old male with long-standing hypertension comes for a routine eye checkup. On fundoscopy, the ophthalmologist observes the following changes as shown in the image below. What is the most likely stage of hypertensive retinopathy?
questions.explanation:
Stage

Key Features

Grade I (Option A)

Mild generalized arteriolar narrowing, broadening of the light reflex.
 

Grade II (Option B)

Focal arteriolar narrowing, A-V nicking (Salu’s sign)

Grade III (Option C)

Flame-shaped hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, and more pronounced A-V nicking (Bonnet and Gunn signs), hemorrhages, and exudates.

Grade IV (Option D)

All features of Grade III + Papilledema, Silver-wiring of arterioles.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with complaints of severe headache and blurred vision. His blood pressure is 220/120 mmHg. Fundoscopy image is given below. Which of the following fundus changes is most characteristic of this diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Finding

Description

Papilledema

Swelling of optic disc due to raised intracranial pressure and optic nerve ischemia

Exudates

Lipid deposits; may form a macular star

Retinal hemorrhages

Flame-shaped hemorrhages, especially in posterior pole

Cotton wool spots

Ischemic infarcts of nerve fiber layer

Venous dilation

Result of vascular congestion

Narrowing of arterioles

Severe vasospasm in acute cases

Elschnig’s spots

Black spots with yellow halos from choroidal infarcts

Siegrist’s streaks

Linear pigmentation along choroidal arterioles from fibrinoid necrosis

Feature

Chronic Hypertensive Retinopathy

Malignant Hypertensive Retinopathy

Arteriolar narrowing

Generalized or focal narrowing, A-V nicking (Option A)

Marked narrowing due to vasospasm

Retinal reflex changes

Copper-wiring (Option B), silver-wiring

Not prominent

Retinal hemorrhages

Few flame-shaped at posterior pole

Numerous flame-shaped hemorrhages

Exudates

Hard exudates, macular-star (Option D)

Focal intraretinal periarterial transudates (FIPTs)

Cotton wool spots

Present

More prominent and widespread

Choroidal involvement

Absent

Elschnig’s spots, Siegrist’s streaks

Optic neuropathy

Absent/minimal

Papilledema, optic nerve ischemia

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with a history of uncontrolled hypertension presents for a routine eye examination. Fundoscopy reveals arteriolar narrowing and changes in the arteriovenous (A-V) ratio. What is the most likely A-V ratio finding in this patient with hypertensive retinopathy?
All of the following are considered risk factors for the development of central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO), except?
questions.explanation:
Factors

Details

Primary Risk Factors
  • Age > 50 years (primary risk factor) (Option A),
  • Hypertension (Option D),
  • Open-angle glaucoma (Option B),
  • Diabetes
  • Hyperlipidemia.

Additional Risk Factors

Smoking, optic disc edema, oral contraceptives, hypercoagulable states (e.g., polycythemia, multiple myeloma, antiphospholipid syndrome, hyperhomocysteinemia, etc.), syphilis, HIV, sickle cell disease.

Pathophysiology

The exact etiology is unknown, but the occlusion of the Central retinal vein posterior to the lamina cribrosa of the optic nerve typically by thrombosis, is a key mechanism. This is contributed by venous stasis and hypercoagulability. Atherosclerosis in the artery can lead to compression of the adjacent vein.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with sudden, severe vision loss in his left eye. On examination, a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is present. Fundus examination reveals the following changes: Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Non-ischemic CRVO (Venous Stasis Retinopathy)

Ischemic CRVO (Hemorrhagic Retinopathy)

Prevalence

75% of cases

25% of cases

Vision

Mild to moderate blurring

Severe, sudden vision loss

RAPD

Absent or mild

Present

Early Fundus Findings

Mild venous congestion, peripheral flame-shaped hemorrhages, mild/no macular edema

Massive venous engorgement, "splashed-tomato" hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, macular edema

Late Fundus Findings

Vein sheathing, cilioretinal collaterals, absorbed hemorrhages, chronic cystoid edema

Marked vein sheathing, collaterals, neovascularization, chronic cystoid edema

Complications

15-30% convert to ischemic CRVO

Neovascular glaucoma, vitreous hemorrhage, proliferative retinopathy

Image

questions.text: Which of the following investigations is most useful in distinguishing ischemic CRVO from non-ischemic CRVO?
questions.explanation:
Investigations

Details

Ocular Examination
  • Visual acuity monitoring
  • IOP measurement
  • Slit-lamp examination for neovascularization of the iris (NVI)
  • Gonioscopy to exclude neovascularization of the angle (NVA)
  • Fundus examination (direct and indirect)

Ocular Investigations
  • Goldmann perimetry: Important for differentiating visual field defects in ischemic from non-ischemic CRVO.
  • ERG: Reduced b-wave amplitude in ischemic CRVO.
  • Fundus autofluorescence (FAF): Demonstrates fern-like perivenular hypo autofluorescence due to retinal edema.
  • FFA: Assess retinal perfusion (Ischemic CRVO shows >10 disc areas of capillary non-perfusion).
  • OCT: To evaluate macular edema, sub-retinal fluid, and epiretinal membrane (ERM) formation.

Systemic Investigations

Check for hypertension, diabetes, dyslipidemia, hypercoagulable states, homocysteinemia.

Medical Treatment
  • Intravitreal steroids (triamcinolone, dexamethasone)
  • Intravitreal anti-VEGF (Bevacizumab, Ranibizumab)

Laser Treatment
  • Panretinal Photocoagulation (PRP): Indicated when neovascularization occurs (NVI, NVA, NVE, or NVD).
  • Grid Laser: Not recommended for macular edema in CRVO.

Surgical Treatment

Pars plana vitrectomy (PPV) for complications (vitreous hemorrhage, retinal detachment, ERM)

Glaucoma drainage devices for neovascular glaucoma.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of hypertension presents with sudden, painless vision loss in his right eye. Which of the following findings is most consistent with the diagnosis of central retinal artery occlusion?

options.label: A
options.text: Retinal hemorrhages and cotton wool spots

options.label: B
options.text: Optic disc edema and retinal hemorrhages

options.label: D
options.text: Pale retina with a cherry-red spot at the macula

questions.correct_answer: D. Pale retina with a cherry-red spot at the macula

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with Type 2 diabetes undergoes a fundus examination, revealing extensive retinal hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, venous beading, and moderate intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA) in one quadrant. What is the most appropriate follow-up interval for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Category

Management

Non-Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (NPDR)

No Diabetic Retinopathy

Review in 12 months

Very Mild NPDR

Microaneurysms only

Review most patients in 12 months

(Option D)

Mild NPDR

Any or all of the: microaneurysms, retinal hemorrhages, exudates, and cotton-wool spots, up to the level of moderate NPDR. No intraretinal microvascular anomalies (IRMA) or significant beading.

Review range 6-12 months, depending on the severity of signs, stability, systemic factors, and patient's circumstances

Moderate NPDR

  • Severe retinal hemorrhages in 1-3 quadrants or mild IRMA
  • Significant venous beading can be present in no more than 1 quadrant
  • Cotton wool spots commonly present

Review in approximately 6 months

(Option C)

Severe NPDR

The 4-2-1 rule; is one or more of the:

  • Severe hemorrhages in all 4 quadrants
  • Significant venous beading in 2 or more quadrants
  • Moderate IRMA in 1 or more quadrants

Review in 4 months (Option B)

Very severe NPDR

Two or more of the criteria for severe NPDR

Review in 2-3 months (Option A)

Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (PDR)

Mild-moderate PDR

New vessels on the disc (NVD) or new vessels elsewhere (NVE), but extent insufficient to meet the high-risk criteria

Treatment is considered according to the severity of signs, stability, systemic factors, and the patient's circumstances such as reliability of attendance for review. If not treated, review in up to 2 months

High-risk PDR

  • NVD greater than ⅓ disc area
  • Any NVD with vitreous hemorrhage
  • NVE greater than ½ disc area with vitreous hemorrhage

Treatment should be performed immediately when possible and certainly on the same day if symptomatic presentation with a good retinal view

Advanced diabetic eye disease

Is characterized by tractional retinal detachment. Significant persistent vitreous hemorrhage and neovascular glaucoma.

Vitreoretinal surgery with photocoagulation

questions.text: A cherry-red spot is seen on the retina due to thickening and loss of transparency of the retina at the posterior pole. Which of the following diseases are least associated with this finding on fundoscopy?

A patient is being examined for loss of vision in the ophthalmology clinic. His peripheral visual field is lost, and only his central vision remains. Which of the following would not present with central (tunnel) vision?

A premature infant, born at 26 weeks of gestation, is receiving oxygen therapy in the neonatal intensive care unit. Retinal examination at 4 weeks post-birth reveals signs of retinal vascular abnormalities. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely responsible for the pathogenesis of retinopathy of prematurity in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased oxygen supply leading to retinal vasodilation

options.label: D
options.text: Retinal hypoxia leading to abnormal collagen formation

questions.text: Which of the following is the most significant risk factor for Retinopathy of Prematurity (ROP)?
questions.correct_answer: B. Prematurity and low birth weight

questions.text: A 32-week premature infant presents with dilated and tortuous retinal vessels in the posterior pole, poor pupil dilation, and vitreous haze, indicating a progression of retinopathy of prematurity (ROP). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Plus Disease

(Option B)

Rush Disease/ Aggressive Posterior ROP

(Option A)

  • Defined by dilatation and tortuosity of posterior pole vessels in at least two quadrants with any stage of ROP.

  • Associated with engorgement and dilatation of the iris vessel, poor pupil dilation and vitreous haze.

  • Indicates a tendency for disease progression.
  • Located in zone I or posterior zone II with severe plus disease.
  • Characterized by flat proliferation with vascular loops, hemorrhages and absence of any stage.
  • Requires immediate treatment due to rapid progression.
  • Can progress directly to stage 5 ROP without passing through earlier stages.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents with sudden, painless vision loss in his left eye. Fundus examination reveals peripheral retinal vasculitis, vessel sheathing and recurrent vitreous hemorrhages. Fluorescein angiography reveals vessel leakage. What is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Description

Population Affected

Young males

Etiology

Hypersensitivity reaction (Type IV or III) to tuberculoproteins, causing retinal vasculitis, resulting in retinal hypoxia and vasoproliferation

Vasculitis Manifestation

Vessel sheathing, extensive leakage on fluorescein angiography

Retinal Changes

Hemorrhages, soft exudates, retinal edema, neovascularization, and arteriovenous shunt vessels

Complications

Recurrent vitreous hemorrhage, tractional retinal detachment, secondary glaucoma

Initial Treatment

Systemic steroids for early vasculitis

Further Management

Photocoagulation for vessels under traction, vitreoretinal surgery for severe cases

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the clinic with a white reflex (leukocoria) noticed in the right eye. An ocular B-scan ultrasound performed to evaluate the child shows a well-defined, echogenic mass within the globe, with associated calcifications. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
What is the approximate distance of the fovea from the optic disc in a normal eye?

options.label: A
options.text: 1 disc diameter temporal to the optic disc

options.label: B
options.text: 2 disc diameters nasal to the optic disc

options.label: C
options.text: 2 disc diameters temporal to the optic disc

options.label: D
options.text: 1 disc diameter nasal to the optic disc

questions.correct_answer: C. 2 disc diameters temporal to the optic disc
questions.explanation:
Structure

Description

Function

Macula lutea (clinical posterior pole)

A 5.5 mm diameter cone-rich region in the retina.

Responsible for central vision and color vision.

Fovea

A 1.5 mm diameter area at the center of the macula, 2 disc diameters temporal to the optic disc.

Provides sharp, detailed vision.

Foveola

A 0.35 mm diameter central depression within the fovea, often shows a bright foveal reflex.

Contains only cones, facilitating the highest visual acuity.

Foveal avascular zone

A 0.4–0.6 mm diameter zone surrounds the foveola, devoid of retinal blood vessels.

Enhances visual clarity by reducing interference from blood vessels.

questions.text: In which layer of the retina, as labeled in the histology image, are the cell bodies of bipolar cells located?
questions.explanation:
Layer

Description

1. Pigment Epithelium

Outermost layer with a single pigmented cell layer; adheres to Bruch's membrane; supports neurosensory retina, and reduces reflection.

Subretinal Space: This is the layer between the Pigment epithelium and the layer of Photoreceptors.

2. Rods and Cones Layer

Contains the outer segments of photoreceptors (rods and cones, which are the first-order neurons); rods detect low-light vision, cones manage color and detailed vision.

3. External Limiting Membrane

A porous membrane allows processes from rods and cones to pass through.

4. Outer Nuclear Layer
(Henle’s layer) (Option D)

Contains the nuclei of the photoreceptor cells (rods and cones).

5. Outer Plexiform Layer (Option C)

Includes connections between rods, cones, bipolar cell dendrites, and horizontal cells.

6. Inner Nuclear Layer (Option B)

Made up of the cell bodies of bipolar cells (which are the second-order neurons), horizontal cells, amacrine cells, and Müller cells; and also contains retinal capillaries.

7. Inner Plexiform Layer (Option A)

Houses synaptic connections between bipolar cell axons, ganglion cell dendrites, and amacrine cell processes.

8. Ganglion Cell Layer

Contains ganglion cell bodies, which serve as third-order neurons; midget cells synapse with a single bipolar cell, and polysynaptic cells synapse with multiple.

9. Nerve Fiber Layer

Composed of ganglion cell axons that form the optic nerve after passing through the lamina cribrosa.

10. Internal Limiting Membrane

The innermost layer separating the retina from the vitreous; is formed by the terminal expansions of Müller cells, serving as a basement membrane.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension and atherosclerosis presents with sudden, painless loss of vision in his left eye. On fundoscopy, you note a pale retina with a cherry-red spot at the macula. What is the most likely underlying cause of this condition?
Which of the following arteries is primarily responsible for supplying the inner layers of the retina?
questions.explanation:
Layer/Region

Blood Supply

Clinical Relevance

Outer four layers

Supplied by the choroidal vascular system (short and long posterior ciliary arteries).

Avascular layers; rely on choroidal vessels for nutrition

Inner six layers

Supplied by the central retinal artery (branch of ophthalmic artery).

Occlusion causes retinal ischemia.

Macula (in some individuals)

Supplied by the cilioretinal artery (from posterior ciliary arteries).

Preserves central vision during CRAO.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of poorly controlled diabetes and hypertension presents with blurred vision. Fundus examination shows bright yellow, well-defined deposits arranged in a star-like pattern around the macula and cloud-like white patches near the optic disc. What is the most likely cause of the yellow deposits?

options.label: A
options.text: Soft exudates due to axoplasmic flow blockage

options.label: B
options.text: Hard exudates due to leakage of lipids and proteins

options.label: D
options.text: Cotton-wool spots from ischemic swelling of nerve fibers

questions.correct_answer: B. Hard exudates due to leakage of lipids and proteins
questions.explanation:
Feature

Soft Exudates (Cotton-Wool Spots)

Hard Exudates

Appearance

Cloud-like, small, ill-defined, whitish patches

Bright yellow, well-defined lipid deposits

Formation Mechanism

Caused by ischemia and axonal swelling; blockage of axoplasmic flow (Option A and D)

Formed by leakage of fluid rich in proteins and lipids

Location

Nerve fibre layer

Seen around leaking microaneurysms (Option C), especially in the macula

Common Shape

Indistinct and variable; may change shape quickly

Radial, star-shaped figure in the macula (macular fan/star)

Main Causes
  • Hypertensive retinopathy
  • Diabetic retinopathy
  • Toxemia of pregnancy
  • Anemic retinopathy
  • Lupus erythematosus (LE)
  • Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN)
  • Scleroderma
  • Leukemic retinopathy
  • Retinopathy associated with AIDS
  • Diabetic retinopathy
  • Hypertensive retinopathy
  • Coats' disease
  • Circinate retinopathy

Image

questions.text: The blood-retinal barrier separates the blood from the ocular cavity. Which of the following does not constitute the outer blood-retinal barrier?
questions.explanation:
Features

Outer blood-retinal barrier

Inner blood-retinal barrier

Components

  • Formed by the adjacent cells of the retinal pigment epithelium(RPE) (Option B).
  • Maintained by tight junctions named “zonula occludens” (Option C).
  • RPE rests on the Bruch’s membrane (Option A), which separates the neural retina from the choroid capillaries.
  • Formed by the tight junctions between the endothelial cells of the retinal blood vessels.
  • Depends on capillary integrity.

Function

It prevents the leakage of extracellular fluid and nutrients from the choroid to the outer retina.

Controls permeability of the retinal blood vessels.

Factors affecting the BRB
  • Prostaglandins
  • Leukotrienes
  • Protein kinase C
  • Nitric oxide
  • VEGF
  • Other cytokines

Associated pathology
  • Outer BRB damage is seen in conditions like:
    • Age-related macular degeneration
    • Central serous chorioretinopathy
    • Accelerated hypertension
    • Toxemia of pregnancy
  • Breakdown of outer BRB leads to:
    • Retinal detachment or
    • RPE detachment
  • Retinal macroaneurysms cause a breakage in the inner blood-retinal barrier and accumulation of fluid within the outer neurosensory retina.
  • Involved in conditions like:
    • Cystoid macular edema.
    • Diabetic retinopathy
    • Retinal vein occlusion

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with a history of diabetes comes in for a routine check-up for diabetic retinopathy. The patient also has a cataract, causing a hazy view of the ocular media. Which method of study would be most appropriate for assessing the retina of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Direct Ophthalmoscopy

Indirect Ophthalmoscopy

Instrument used

Image
  • Erect, virtual
  • Inverted, real

Magnification
  • High magnification
  • (~15x in emmetropes, more in myopes, less in hypermetropes)
  • Moderate magnification (~2.5x with a +20D lens)

Field of View
  • Small (~10° or 1-2 disc diameters)
  • Large (~35° or 8 disc diameters)

Visualization
  • Central retina only
  • Central and peripheral retina (up to the ora serrata)

Refractive Media
  • Poor visualization in hazy or cloudy media (Option A)
  • Can visualize through hazy media due to stronger illumination (option B)

Examination Distance
  • Close to the eye (~15 mm from the cornea)
  • Performed at a greater distance (~50 cm or an arm’s length)

Patient Position
  • Performed in a seated/standing position in a semi-dark room
  • Performed with the patient in a supine or sitting position

Lens Requirement
  • No external lens is required; correcting lenses for refractive errors are built into the ophthalmoscope
  • Requires a convex lens (commonly +20D) to be placed in front of the patient’s eye

Peripheral Lesion Detection
  • Limited ability to detect peripheral lesions
  • Excellent for detecting peripheral retinal lesions such as retinal detachment or tears.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with age-related macular degeneration (ARMD) undergoes Fundus Fluorescein Angiography (FFA), revealing pooling of dye under the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) and leakage from newly formed vessels beneath the retina. What abnormality is most likely detected on FFA in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Hyperfluorescence due to dye pooling under detached RPE and neovascularization

options.label: B
options.text: Hypofluorescence due to blockage of background fluorescence by retinal hemorrhage

options.label: C
options.text: Hypofluorescence due to occlusion of retinal vasculature

options.label: D
options.text: Hyperfluorescence due to staining of the optic disc

questions.correct_answer: A. Hyperfluorescence due to dye pooling under detached RPE and neovascularization
questions.explanation:
Fluorescence Type

Cause

Examples

Hyperfluorescence

Window defect in retinal pigment epithelium (RPE)

Atrophy showing background choroidal fluorescence

Pooling of dye under detached RPE

Age-related macular degeneration (ARMD) (Option A)

Pooling of dye under sensory retina

Central serous retinopathy (CSR)

Leakage into the neurosensory retina due to the breakdown of the inner blood-retinal barrier

Cystoid macular edema (CME)

Leakage from choroidal or retinal neovascularization

Proliferative diabetic retinopathy, subretinal neovascular membrane in ARMD

Staining (long retention of dye by tissues)

Drusen, normal optic disc (Option D)

Leakage from optic nerve head

Papilloedema

Hypofluorescence

Blockage of background fluorescence

Retinal hemorrhage (Option B), hard exudates, pigmented clumps

Occlusion of retinal/choroidal vasculature

Central retinal artery occlusion (Option C), diabetic retinopathy capillary occlusion

Loss of vasculature

Choroideremia, myopic degeneration

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with difficulty in vision, especially at night, and he reports bumping into objects frequently. Upon examination, he is found to have tunnel vision, and the fundus reveals no abnormalities in the posterior pole. Which region of the retina is most likely responsible for his symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Part

Description

Posterior Pole

The region behind the retinal equator includes the optic disc and macula lutea; best examined using slit-lamp biomicroscopy or by direct ophthalmoscopy.

Optic Disc (Option C)

Known as the optic nerve head, it is a pink, vertically oval structure, marking the start of the optic nerve.

The physiological Cup is a depression in the optic disc through which the central retinal artery and vein pass; the absence of photoreceptors results in the physiological blind spot.

Macula Lutea (Option A)

A dark, yellow spot at the posterior pole, measuring 5.5 mm in diameter; is responsible for central, high-acuity vision and color detection.

Fovea Centralis (Option B)

Central area of the macula (1.5 mm in diameter); contains only cones and is the most sensitive part of the retina for visual acuity.

Foveola

A 0.35 mm diameter shining pit within the fovea, represents the area of highest visual acuity, with the foveal avascular zone (FAZ) surrounding it.

Peripheral Retina (Option D)

Extends from the retinal equator to the ora serrata, examined via indirect ophthalmoscopy or Goldmann three-mirror lens. It contains rods, hence responsible for night vision.

Ora Serrata

The serrated peripheral margin is where the retina ends. Here the retina is firmly attached to both the vitreous and choroid. Pars plana extends anteriorly from ora serrata.

questions.text: Which of the following electroretinogram (ERG) findings suggests gross disturbances in retinal circulation?

options.label: A
options.text: Extinguished ERG response B) Subnormal ERG with a reduced b-wave C) Negative ERG response D) Normal ERG with a diminished c-wave

options.label: B
options.text: Subnormal ERG with a reduced b-wave

options.label: D
options.text: Normal ERG with a diminished c-wave

questions.explanation:
Definition

Electroretinography (ERG) records changes in the eye's resting potential. It is induced by a flash of light.

Parts of ERG
  • A-wave: Negative wave, likely from rods and cones (photoreceptors).
  • B-wave: Large positive wave, generated by Müller cells (inner retinal layers) but reflects bipolar cell activity.
  • C-wave: Positive wave, related to the metabolic activity of the pigment epithelium (RPE), observed in dark-adapted eyes.
  • Foveal ERG provides information about the macula used in diagnosing cataracts.

Interpretation

Response

Inference

Extinguished

Complete failure in rod and cone function (e.g., pigmentary retinal dystrophy, complete retinal artery occlusion, old retinal detachment, advanced siderosis).

Subnormal

Large areas of the retina not functioning (e.g., early retinitis pigmentosa, before ophthalmoscopic signs).

Negative

Gross disturbances in the retinal circulation.

Clinical uses
  • Used in diagnosis and prognosis for retinal disorders like retinitis pigmentosa, Leber's congenital amaurosis, retinal ischemia, and chorioretinal degenerations.
  • Assessment in Unclear Conditions: Evaluates retinal junction when fundus examination is not possible (e.g., dense cataract, corneal opacity).
  • Infant Vision Assessment: Assesses retinal junction in infants with suspected impaired vision.

Patterns in ERG

Pattern ERG

Changes in PERG responses can occur in the early stages of glaucoma by measuring the activity of retinal ganglion cells (RGCs), often correlating with elevated intraocular pressure (IOP).

Multifocal ERG
  • mfERG aids in diagnosing macular diseases like Stargardt dystrophy, cone dystrophy, and occult macular dystrophy.
  • mfERG or similar objective tests can be used to screen chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine toxicity.

questions.text: A patient with chronic diabetes mellitus complains of diminished vision. Her fundoscopy showed clinically significant macular edema. Which of the following would not be seen as a progressive change leading to diabetic retinopathy?
questions.explanation:
Retinal vascular disorders
  • Diabetic retinopathy
  • Retinal venous occlusive disease
  • Retinopathy of prematurity
  • Sickle cell retinopathy
  • Retinal artery occlusive disease, etc.











 

General pathogenesis

 
  • Diabetic retinopathy (DR):
  • Capillary basement membrane thickening, endothelial cell damage, RBCs deformation, and rouleaux formation, increased stickiness of platelets, increased plasma viscosity, loss of capillary pericytes → microvascular occlusion (cotton wool spots), retinal ischemia → leads to the clinical appearances of DR.
  • Progress of retinal changes in diabetic retinopathy:
    • Diabetic macular edema → Macular ischemia (Option A) → Retinal new vessels (Option B) → Vitreous hemorrhage (Option C) → Tractional retinal detachment.

Hypertensive retinopathy:

  • Systemic hypertension causes vasoconstriction of retinal arterioles (Option D)
  • Arteriosclerosis, increased vascular permeability, and retinal hemorrhages lead to retinopathy.

Retinopathy of prematurity:

  • In premature infants
  • Linked to high-oxygen exposure
  • Leads to abnormal neovascularization and retinal hypoxia

Sickle cell retinopathy:

  • Due to abnormal RBCs
  • Vascular occlusion and retinal damage lead to retinopathy.

options.label: B
options.text: Grid laser acts on diffuse retinal thickening, at least 500 µm from the fovea and optic disc.

options.label: C

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: A. Focal laser therapy for diabetic macular edema targets leaking microaneurysms within 300 µm of the fovea.
questions.explanation:
Condition

Therapy

Details

Diabetic retinopathy

Diabetic Macular Edema (DMO)

Focal laser

Targets leaking microaneurysms within 500 µm of the fovea

Grid laser

Applied to areas of diffuse retinal thickening, at least 500 µm from the fovea and optic disc (Option B)

Modified Grid Laser

Combines focal treatment with grid laser for diffuse thickening

Subthreshold (micropulse) diode laser

Uses very short pulses with longer intervals, minimizing collateral damage (Option C) while stimulating RPE, and allows subfoveal treatment.

Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (PDR)

Scatter laser treatment - Panretinal Photocoagulation (PRP)

Mainstay treatment; applies laser burns to peripheral retina to induce regression of neovascularization.

Targeted Retinal Photocoagulation

Utilizes FA to target peripheral capillary non-perfusion, aiming for neovascularization regression.

Branch Retinal Vein Occlusion (BRVO)

Sector Photocoagulation

Targets on ischemic areas, often combined with anti-VEGF injections.

Macular Laser

Considered for persistent macular edema with good central perfusion.

Subthreshold Laser

Alternative for macular edema treatment

Central Retinal Vein Occlusion (CRVO)

Panretinal Photocoagulation (PRP)

Crucial for treating neovascularization, often supplemented with anti-VEGF injections.

Sickle Cell Retinopathy

Laser or Cryotherapy

Ablates peripheral non-perfused retina to minimize neovascularization stimulus.

Coats Disease

Laser Ablation

Targets leaking areas, often requiring multiple treatments.

Eales Disease

Scatter Photocoagulation or Cryotherapy

Treats non-perfused retina to reduce neovascularization.

Limitations and considerations

(Option D)
  • Visual field defects
  • Central vision risks
  • Multiple sessions
  • Informed consent

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic patient presents with worsening vision. Fundoscopy reveals retinal edema, microaneurysms, and hard exudates. Which of the following mechanisms is not responsible for the development of diabetic retinopathy?

A 55-year-old patient with a long history of diabetes mellitus presents for a routine eye examination. The ophthalmologist noted several findings in the retinal examination. Which of the following features is least likely to be observed in early nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR)?
questions.explanation:
Severity

Definition

Very mild nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy

Microaneurysms only

Mild nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy

Microaneurysms plus hard exudates, cotton-wool spots, and/or mild retinal hemorrhages

Moderate nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy

Microaneurysms plus mild intraretinal microvascular abnormalities or moderate retinal hemorrhages

Severe nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy

Any one of the following (4-2-1 Rule)

  • Severe retinal hemorrhages in four quadrants
  • Venous beading in at least two
  • Moderately severe intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA) in at least one quadrant

Very severe nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy

Any two of the following (4-2-1 Rule)

  • Severe retinal hemorrhages in four quadrants
  • Venous beading in at least two
  • Moderately severe intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA) in at least one quadrant

Early NPDR or Background Diabetic Retinopathy

Severe NPDR or Preproliferative Diabetic Retinopathy
  • Affects small retinal vessels.
  • Earliest sign: Microaneurysm (Option A)
    • Fluorescein angiography (FA): Tiny hyperfluorescent dots.
  • Retinal hemorrhages: Both deep, i.e., in the inner nuclear or outer plexiform layer (dot and blot hemorrhage) and superficial, i.e., in nerve fiber layer (splinter or flame-shaped) hemorrhages (Option B)
  • Hard exudates:
    • White or yellow waxy patches with well-defined margins, often at the posterior pole, in the outer plexiform layer. (Option C)
    • FA: Hypofluorescence with dense exudates.
  • Edema is not marked.
  • Increased inner retinal hypoxia: Leads to multiple retinal hemorrhages, cotton-wool spots, venous beading, vascular loops, intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMAs), and large areas of capillary nonperfusion.
  • Cotton-Wool Spots:
    • Also called soft exudates or nerve fiber infarcts.
    • Result from ischemia, not exudation.
    • Caused by obstruction of axoplasmic flow, leading to swelling and a white, fluffy appearance.
    • FA: Focal hypofluorescence due to local ischemia.
  • Venous Beading:
    • Indicates sluggish retinal circulation.
    • Typically adjacent to large areas of capillary nonperfusion. (Option D)
  • Intraretinal Microvascular Abnormalities (IRMA):
    • Dilated capillaries act as collateral channels.
    • Bypass capillary bed and is often seen adjacent to capillary nonperfusion.
    • FA: Focal hypofluorescence
